items.title: Legendary Canadian actress Catherine O'Hara dead at 71
Hyundai interested in Canada's hydrogen energy as it bets on decarbonized cars
items.summary_auto: Hyundai is exploring a "potential collaboration" with the Canadian hydrogen energy sector, it told CBC News on Thursday, as the South Korean automaker bets on decarbonized cars to be the future of the automotive industry.

items.title: Jim Pattison won't sell U.S. warehouse proposed as new ICE facility
items.summary_auto: Jim Pattison Developments has announced it will not sell an industrial building in Ashland, Va., that was set to be turned into an Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) processing facility.

items.title: As GM Oshawa layoffs begin, workers leave the plant and enter an uncertain job market
items.summary_auto: Friday marks the last day of work for up to 1,200 autoworkers, as GM cuts one of three shifts at its Oshawa plant. Some workers say they are looking out of province to find employment in the face of Oshawa's 8.6 per cent unemployment rate.

items.title: Appeal court rules in favour of Ottawa's toxic plastic listing
'We were within the rules,’ Canadian skeleton coach denies sabotaging U.S. slider
items.summary_auto: In an exclusive interview with CBC Sports, Canadian skeleton coach Joe Cecchini denies that he manipulated a race on the developmental circuit to ensure Canada’s spots at the Olympics, ultimately preventing American Katie Uhlaender from competing in a record sixth Games.

items.title: Prosecutors can't seek death penalty against Luigi Mangione, judge rules
items.summary_auto: Federal prosecutors can’t seek the death penalty against Luigi Mangione in the killing of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson, a judge ruled Friday, foiling the Trump administration’s bid to see him executed for what it called a “premeditated, cold-blooded assassination that shocked America.”

items.title: Former CNN anchor Don Lemon arrested after protest inside Minneapolis church
items.summary_auto: Journalist Don Lemon and three other people were arrested Friday in connection with an anti-immigration enforcement protest that disrupted a service at a Minnesota church and increased tensions between residents and federal officials.

items.title: Former Mountie found guilty of perjury related to fellow officer's trial
items.summary_auto: A provincial court judge has found a former police officer guilty of perjury and says the man lied to protect his own interests during the trial for a colleague.

items.title: Canada's economy stalled in November, may have contracted in 4th quarter of 2025
items.summary_auto: Canada's economic growth stalled in November as growth in services was ​offset by weakness in goods-producing industries, data showed on Friday, offering fresh clues on the state of the economy after almost a year of tariffs and uncertainty.

items.title: Trump's latest tariff threat has targeted Canada's aviation industry. Here's how reaction unfolded
Trump aviation threats that would affect Bombardier, Gulfstream and others: What we know
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump's latest grievance threatening to upend the deeply integrated economic ties between the U.S. and Canada involves business jets. Here's what we know so far.

items.title: ‘Targets on their back’: Trading card shops, collectors face rising thefts
items.summary_auto: Trading card shops like ShoeBox Games & Cafe in Calgary are being targeted for thefts, as Pokemon trading cards have skyrocketed in value over recent years.

items.title: Israel says Gaza's Rafah crossing with Egypt will reopen on Sunday
items.summary_auto: Israel will reopen the Rafah border crossing on Sunday for people to travel between Gaza and Egypt, a government agency said, the first opening of effectively the sole route in or out of the Palestinian territory since May 2024.

items.title: Dozens of houses evacuated in Badger, N.L., as river levels rise
items.summary_auto: "We're at the mercy of Mother Nature," Mayor Dennis Butt told CBC News on Friday. The state of emergency remains in place for the town.

items.title: Lindsey Vonn says 'Olympic dream is not over' after crashing in last downhill before Winter Games
items.summary_auto: Lindsey Vonn crashed in her final downhill race before the Winter Olympics on Friday and was airlifted from the course for medical checks, a troubling turn for the 41-year-old U.S. ski star just a week before the Milano-Cortina Games.

items.title: How a B.C. court case could change medical assistance in dying across Canada
items.summary_auto: The policy that allows faith-based health-care providers to ban medical assistance in dying in their facilities is being tested now in B.C. Supreme Court. But transfers of MAID patients because the facility won't allow the practice are more common outside B.C., according to Health Canada data.

items.title: Alberta heart, cancer patients waiting too long for critical surgery, health experts warn
items.summary_auto: While a record number of surgeries is being performed in the province, the number of people on Alberta's waitlist is longer than it was two years ago. And the latest provincial data shows less than two-thirds of patients had their surgeries completed within the recommended time period.

items.title: Trump names former Fed official turned critic Kevin Warsh as his pick for next chair
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump said Friday that he will nominate former Federal Reserve official Kevin Warsh to be the next chair of the Fed, a decision likely to result in sharp changes to the powerful agency that could bring it closer to the White House.

items.title: Real-life Heated Rivalry: Sask. man recounts coming out to college hockey teammates
items.summary_auto: While playing college hockey in 2019, Brock Weston called a locker room meeting and came out to his teammates. He expected some backlash, but found overwhelming support.

items.title: Law to prevent domestic violence on the books for 3 years, but still not in effect
items.summary_auto: The law is meant to give police legal authority to share information that advocates say could prevent cases of intimate partner violence.

items.title: Accessible cabs in Toronto are dwindling. One company says the city is failing to support drivers
items.summary_auto: One of the largest taxi companies in Toronto will be down to three wheelchair-accessible cabs by the end of March, leaving a gap in options for accessible road transportation. Some advocates and providers say the city is failing to support accessible taxi drivers.

items.title: 'Mixed' results on N.B.’s targets, premier admits in state of province speech after 1st year in office
items.summary_auto: The government has hit 10 of its 15 short-term performance targets laid out by Premier Susan Holt, but has fallen back on one of the most top-of-mind objectives for New Brunswickers.

items.title: Cape Breton groups alarmed as more Atlantic salmon deemed endangered
items.summary_auto: Some Atlantic salmon conservation groups in Cape Breton are raising the alarm after a federal advisory committee changed the fish's status to endangered throughout Nova Scotia and the southern Gulf of St. Lawrence.

items.title: Think you're buying Canadian at the grocery store? That product may actually be from the U.S.
So long, frozen juice from concentrate. The once-popular canned drink leaves shelves this year
items.summary_auto: Attention, lemonade stand vendors: You'll have to squeeze the fresh stuff this summer. Minute Maid is discontinuing its line of frozen juices as consumers turn to healthier beverages, and it was potentially the last company selling the concentrated cans in the Canadian market.

items.title: He was a high school math whiz. Now he’s a Canadian crypto fugitive trying to hide from the world
items.summary_auto: Documents from extradition proceedings at the Belgrade Higher Court obtained by the fifth estate and the Balkan Investigative Reporting Network provide an extraordinary glimpse into the lifestyle and whereabouts of a young Canadian man with an alleged $65 million US in cryptocurrency burning a hole in his pocket and multiple countries seeking his arrest.

items.title: Why members of ICE will be in Italy for the Winter Olympics
items.summary_auto: A unit of ICE will be in Italy to work during the upcoming Winter Games. Yes, that ICE. Who exactly will be there and what will they be doing?

items.title: Ontario PCs gather this weekend, as some conservatives push for change in government’s direction
items.summary_auto: Ontario’s Progressive Conservatives will huddle behind closed doors at a policy convention this weekend as some Tories question the party’s direction after nearly eight years in power.

items.title: Fake passports, $65M US and an Interpol Red Notice: Canadian crypto fugitive vanishes after arrest in Serbia
items.summary_auto: Documents from extradition proceedings at the Belgrade Higher Court obtained by the fifth estate and the Balkan Investigative Reporting Network provide an extraordinary glimpse into the lifestyle and whereabouts of a young Canadian man with an alleged $65 million US in cryptocurrency burning a hole in his pocket and multiple countries seeking his arrest.

items.title: Damage, disruption and 2 deaths under investigation following Montreal power outage
items.summary_auto: After days without power in sub-zero temperatures, residents in Montreal’s west end are dealing with widespread property damage, as two deaths possibly linked to the outage are now under investigation.

items.title: Poilievre to pitch members on keeping his job as Conservative leader in convention speech
items.summary_auto: Conservative Leader Pierre Poilievre will take to the stage Friday for what could be one of the most important speeches of his political career as he tries to convince delegates at the party's Calgary convention to keep him in the job.

items.title: 'Minnetoba'? Some Minnesotans want to join Canada as tensions flare with Trump administration
items.summary_auto: A former Minnesota governor recently pitched a novel solution to the state’s clashes with the Trump administration: join Canada. He's not the first, nor only, one in the state looking north.

items.title: Trio of European teams to watch at the Olympic women's hockey tournament
items.summary_auto: Canada or the U.S. have won every world championship and Olympic title. But these European teams are looking to shake up the podium at Milano Cortina 2026.

items.title: Road salt alternatives? They're out there, but it's about cost as much as chemistry
items.summary_auto: As London, Ont., deals with a deep freeze and a shortage of road salt, researchers at Western University say they're looking into some ice-clearing alternatives.

items.title: #TheMoment a snowplow inspired a winter protest song
items.summary_auto: Danny MacNeil tells The National about the moment he wrote a song about his hatred for shoveling snow in Sydney, N.S.

items.title: Data breach at Canada Computers & Electronics leaks personal customer information
items.summary_auto: Canada Computers & Electronics says a data breach has leaked information about some of its customers, though several say they are unhappy with the scant details the retailer has provided — including how many of them were affected, and when the breach occurred.

items.title: Record number of organ transplants recorded in 2025: B.C. Transplant
items.summary_auto: B.C. Transplant said the latest data shows 2025 saw the highest number of organ transplants done in the province.

items.title: Using AI to read mammograms cut risk of developing aggressive breast cancer, study finds
items.summary_auto: When radiologists used artificial intelligence to help read mammograms, the rate of detection of breast cancers increased, resulting in fewer aggressive and advanced cases, a large trial in Sweden has found.

items.title: Nicki Minaj declared herself Trump's 'No. 1 fan.' Why is that controversial?
items.summary_auto: Rapper Nicki Minaj on Wednesday declared herself U.S. President Donald Trump’s “No. 1 fan,” before showing off a gold card visa.
